group_1.textRight: And who do we have here?

group_1.textLeft: Traveling Coordinator's my day job, but I'm@takin' a little time off for this interview.
I trust ya don't need th' full rundown,@now do ya, Prof?

group_1.textRight: Well now...it would seem you've@already fathomed why I've come.

group_1.textLeft: Even I ain't fathomed what's goin'@down in that head o' yours, Prof.
So no, I dunno the details.
But Nayuta jus' wants to know what you know.

group_1.textRight: I take it the biggest question you@have is why I disappeared?

group_1.textLeft: Yes, I know you disappeared and@I didn't hear from you.
But I also want to hear about you and Uncle@spreading the truth about Magical Girls.
So I want you to tell me everything,@starting from the beginning!

group_1.textRight: ...Everything is somewhat intertwined,@so it's difficult to explain in a concise way.
Shall we start with the events before my@disappearance?

group_1.narration: I started believing in Magical Girls@after I discovered that Nayuta had become one,@and from the point I started investigating,@there was something that bothered me.
It was the fact that Magical Girls must have@existed throughout the whole of human history,@without being known to the public conscience.
Not only did they protect us from Witches,@they also helped evolve humanity and@were substantial influences upon history,@and yet they were somehow relegated only to the shadows.
The discrepancy between these accounts@had me hooked.

I traveled abroad, looking for traces of Magical Girls,@looking for women who left an impact on history,@and I came up with the hypothesis that Magical Girls@themselves have had different names depending@on the era and culture they were in.
Expressions that exaggerate the facts,@and describe fantasies as though they were facts,@are apparent in literature.
It's a common theory that those in power@came up with these fantasies to show their authority,@and that these live on as myths and hero stories.
According to what Kyubey told Nayuta about@Magical Girls existing in ancient times,@it doesn't seem strange that Magical Girls were@at the core of those myths and hero stories.
However, no matter how far back you go,@no matter how much you reexamine it,@what is written about in the literature of myths and@heroes never differs from the realm of dreams and visions.
Even though there should be Magical Girls in any era,@just like Nayuta or Touka, there was never@any universal recognition, and their names@are left only in legends.
Then what happens to the ordinary Magical Girls@who don't go on to become legends...?
They don't talk about them defeating Witches,@they don't talk about their Wish,@they just act like they're preprogrammed@to hide their identity.
There was a group of Magical Girls in Kamihama City@a couple of years back that supported@that idea particularly well.
At the time,@they were divided between East and West,@and they shed their blood fighting over Witches.
But they didn't want to tell anyone about@their suffering, and they kept about@their daily lives, pretending to be okay.
That sense of incongruity did not change@when I visited Futatsugi City.
And that sense of incongruity only got more@complicated as I saw Magical Girls who@seemingly didn't complain about their plight@nor the state of the town.
It was strange that we never took issue@with the materials and Magical Girls@that remained in history.
The fighting between Magical Girls was causing@unnatural deaths, but why were they always left@as natural events with no concern paid?
I was puzzled by this strange phenomenon...

Even so, that's why...!@There was meaning in spreading the existence@of Magical Girls to the world,@so I wrote "Magical Girls: Their Hope and Despair".@I finished writing the first volume and@started work on the second.
After that, I visited the Tokime village,@but when I started investigating the shrine there,@I got kicked out by the village's head, Mikoshiba,@so I started to concentrate on writing instead.
But as Nayuta is sure to remember,@when I continued work on the second volume,@I became ill and couldn't write anymore.
So, since I wished with all my heart to be able@to keep writing, I changed my base to Yukuni City so I@could keep up with my work while healing at the hot springs.
There, Magical Girls were at least known@to the students of the town.
Although only partially,@it was a form of what I wanted to accomplish.
But it was a living hell for Magical Girls.

group_1.textRight: I learned that telling the world about Magical@Girls would, conversely, only create despair...
However, I was too afraid to@share this hypothesis with you...
That our purpose was blighted@by an impossibly cruel outcome.
I didn't want to burden you with that@while it was still only a possibility.
So, until I was able to fully test the hypothesis@I'd come up with, until it was all over...
I decided I had to disappear...

group_1.narration: [chara:802401:effect_shake]*Slap*!

group_1.textCenter: Don't you dare look down on me!
